Amiss to tumble on the bed of Ptolemy,
To give a kingdom for a mirth, to sit

[3] A devotion said at morning, noon, and evening, at the sound of a

12:00.quote:

cloudless day; the ascent was gradual, and the glimpses, from under

cliffs, were as charming as glimpses of dreamland
12:00.title: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court
12:00.author: Mark Twain

12:00.quote:
It was twelve o'clock noon, and a breezy,
cloudless day; the ascent was gradual, and the glimpses, from under

cliffs, were as charming as glimpses of dreamland

12:00.quote:
We got under way about the turn of noon, and pulled out for the summit

12:00.quote:

Sequel: before noon, next day, he was in the

12:00.author: Mark Twain

And why do they not discover, when "in the noon of

‘Mrs

Now, if you’ll believe me, she hasn’t come out of that house since noon
to-day

12:00.author: Charles Dickens

It

_(The morning and noon hours waltz in their places, turning, advancing

FROM NOON TO STARRY NIGHT


Thou Orb Aloft Full-Dazzling

12:00.quote:

So, I’ll
come back at noon.”

With these reflections, the old man was shutting the gate of the little

“Think of her pretending to set up a cent-shop, and then lying abed

waiting-woman, gave it to him privately on the stairs, as she was about
to get into a sedan, telling him I would give him a crown if he gave it
me as I came off parade.”

“Noon

12:00.quote:
At noon the yellow lions
come down to the water’s edge to drink

12:00.title: The Happy Prince and Other Tales
12:00.author: Oscar Wilde

12:00.quote: Sisters, it is nearly noon
12:00.title: Little Dorrit
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
Here, the party straightway retired to rest; the refreshment of sleep
being necessary after so long a journey; and here they met again
about noon, to a substantial breakfast, spread by direction of Mr

12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
For the third and last article, I
require that you execute a bond to me, this day, binding yourself in the
payment of these two sums, before noon of the day of your marriage with
Madeline Bray
12:00.title: Little Dorrit
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
One
night’s unbroken rest, and I should be a man again.’

Pushing the table from him while he spoke, as though he loathed the
sight of food, he encountered the watch: the hands of which were almost
upon noon
12:00.title: Little Dorrit
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote: ‘This is strange!’ he said; ‘noon, and Noggs not here
12:00.title: Little Dorrit
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
He accusing me of being impatient, and he the very man who has been
wearying us morning, noon, and night, and torturing us for leave to go

we had arranged a single thing
12:00.title: Little Dorrit
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
And hedged with cruel thorns and set with briars;
  We stumble onward, or we pause to weep,
    And still the hard road baffles our desires,
  And still the hot noon beats, the hours delay,
  The end is out of sight,—Art Thou the way
12:00.title: The Vicomte de Bragelonne
12:00.author: Alexandre Dumas

12:00.quote:
The flowers of May and the roses of June,
    The sweet spring-breath of the April breeze,
  The dew of morn and the light of noon—
    When we give up Freya, must we give all these
12:00.title: The Vicomte de Bragelonne
12:00.author: Alexandre Dumas

12:00.quote:
Friendship laid fetters on the noon,
    And fate threw sudden burdens down,
  And hours were short and strength failed soon,
    And darkness came the day to drown,
    Hope changed to grief and smile to frown
12:00.title: The Vicomte de Bragelonne
12:00.author: Alexandre Dumas

12:00.quote:
A little after noon on that distinguished Saturday I reached the ship and
went on board

dictated a run for shelter

12:00.title: The Rights of Man

At the end of three hours of boding suspense, they
came back and said the Emperor would receive us at noon the next day

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

We left Damascus at noon and rode across the plain a couple of hours, and

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

At noon we halted before the wretched Arab town

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

At noon we took a swim in the Sea of Galilee--a blessed privilege in this

12:00.quote:
To satisfy himself that this spot was really the centre of the earth, a

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

At noon we would reach Carson City, the capital of

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

Next day, toward noon, the
figures were all in the purser's hands in sealed envelopes

And filled us with alarm

Flowers bloom there, always, the reader can easily

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
The

which had been there twenty-four hours
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote: It was just after noon, on a bright October day
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
At noon I observed a bevy of nude native young ladies bathing in the sea,
and went and sat down on their clothes to keep them from being stolen

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
At noon, we hired a Kanaka to take us down to the ancient ruins at

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
It was like gazing at the sun at noon-day, except that the glare was not

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
It's always sunrise with that man, and
fine and blazing, at that--never gets noon; though--leaves off and rises

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
"We learn that as the down noon express was leaving H---- yesterday
     a lady

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
Ten of the
     opposition were called away from town about noon,(but--so it is
     said--only for one day)

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
George Selby and family, who had taken passage and were to sail at

12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
About the
middle of the after noon he put on his roughest clothes and went to the

12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
About noon a
great avenue was reached, which had in it two endless parallel bars of

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
This morning the Venus will be removed to the Capitol, there to

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
When?"

"At noon

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

seemed to him that the noon recess would never come

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

CHAPTER XI

CLOSE upon the hour of noon the whole village was suddenly electrified

CHAPTER XXVI

ABOUT noon the next day the boys arrived at the dead tree; they had
come for their tools
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
I tell you, many's
the time I wished I had some when I was in there before."

A trifle after noon the boys borrowed a small skiff from a citizen who
was absent, and got under way at once

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

By noon the broken legs were all set, but

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

They prayed an hour--two hours--three hours--and so

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

It was past noon, therefore they ordered their landlord,
downstairs, to send up hot beefsteaks, chickens, and such things,

whilst they chatted, disputed and laughed

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

Toward noon we heard the inspiring cry:

"Sail ho!"

"Where away?" shouted the captain

[Figure 4]

At noon we stepped ashore and bought some bottled beer
and got some chickens cooked, while the raft waited;
then we immediately put to sea again, and had our
dinner while the beer was cold and the chickens hot

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

"There is one man who is deeply grateful for that

the ascent was gradual, and the glimpses, from under
the curtaining boughs, of blue water, and tiny sailboats,
and beetling cliffs, were as charming as glimpses of dreamland
12:00.title: The Rights of Man

12:00.quote:
It was
twelve o'clock noon, and a breezy, cloudless day;
the ascent was gradual, and the glimpses, from under
the curtaining boughs, of blue water, and tiny sailboats,
and beetling cliffs, were as charming as glimpses of dreamland

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

We got under way about the turn of noon, and pulled out
for the summit again, with a fresh and vigorous step

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

Before twelve o'clock we had found a good position

A little after noon we ended the ascent and arrived at the

he was safe in the city lockup--booked for three months

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

About noon, after a long and weary tramp, the gang came to a halt behind

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

At noon he was still tramping--among the rabble which followed after the

12:00.quote:
I want to leave at twelve o'clock.'

'I don't know about that

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
'I will detail a pilot to
go with you, and he shall be on board at twelve o'clock.'

'But if I discharge S----, he will come on me for the whole season's
wages.'

'Of course that is a matter between you and Mr

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

But as sure as I am
standing here on this ground on this particular brick,--there, I've

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

Troy: March 27, 1882, noon

So the next day after the funeral, along about noon-time, the girls' joy

528, O.S., and

Saturday noon I went to the well and looked on a while

nest before noon to-morrow, if the Church's hand hasn't lost its

TOM RESPECTS THE FLEA

"NOON!" says Tom, and so it was

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

Has
he be'n to see you?"

"Ye-s."

"When?"

"Monday noon."

"Monday noon

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

Presently she said:

"You seed dat man at noon, las' Monday?"

"Yes."

"I seed him de middle o' dat arternoon

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
"Did you he'p him fix up de bill?"

Tom cursed himself for making that stupid blunder, and tried to rectify

CHAPTER IV

SUPERNATURAL CHRONOMETRY

Rowena was dining out, Joe and Harry were belated at play, there
were but three chairs and four persons that noon at the home
dinner-table--the twins, the widow, and her chum, Aunt Betsy Hale

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

oath, that the leg-power passed from one to the other every Saturday

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

2, and would be
followed by others till twelve o'clock should arrive, and Luigi would get

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

I went the next afternoon, and took an obscure lodging; the next day I
called at the castle and paid my respects to the governor, who invited me
to dine with him at noon of the following day

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

I came again to the castle the next day at noon, and was conducted to the

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
I woke at noon out of such a solid and stupefying sleep that at first my
wits were all astray, and I did not know where I was nor what had been

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
Chapter 18 Joan's First Battle-Field

ABOUT NOON I was chatting with Madame Boucher; nothing was going on, all
was quiet, when Catherine Boucher suddenly entered in great excitement,
and said:

"Fly, sir, fly
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

She pounded it with
artillery all the forenoon, then about noon she ordered an assault and
led it herself
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
When it was sufficiently crippled the
assault was sounded at noon, and it was carried by storm
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
"I have done neither since yesterday at noon."

The priest shifted to the Voices again

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
And thus we
reached the noon of that fearful Thursday

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

"Well, to cut the tale short, we never left there till plumb noon; and
long before that I was hid in this stateroom; for before breakfast I see
a man coming, away off, that had a gait like Hal Clayton's, and it made
me just sick
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote: Here at noon what do we see
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
Think
what we've done: four miles there, two to Moseley's, is six, then back to
here--nine miles since noon, and not a bite to eat; I declare I don't see
how we've done it; and as for me, I am just famishing

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote: Closing in on the equator this noon
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
At noon I took a thermometer graded to 127 deg., out of
     my box, and observed that the mercury was up to 125
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
FROM DIARY:

November 1--noon

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

They agreed; the papers were drawn
out and signed, and at noon, Saturday, word was sent to the poor old
woman
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
in order to be sure to be perfect with his history
lesson by noon
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
In
other ships there is always an eager rush to the bulletin board at noon
to find out what the "run" has been; in these seas the bulletin seems to

visited it only once

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

The next morning he left his camp at Mount
Pleasant and marched out and crossed the Ingogo river with 270 men,
started up the Ingogo heights, and there fought a battle which lasted

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
To-day we changed to one
     meal, and that at about noon, with a small ration or water at 8 or 9
     A.M., another at 12 A.M., and a third at 5 or 6 P.M

12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
But they
must manage somehow for five days more, for at noon they have still eight
hundred miles to go
12:00.title: The Rights of Man
12:00.author: Thomas Paine

12:00.quote:
They prayed an hour--two hours--three hours--and so

By noon the entertainment had
fairly begun and we were told that it would last during the whole of

12:00.quote:

zenith, intimating that our visit must be deferred until noon

12:00.author: Niccolò Machiavelli

12:00.quote:

fruit would be heaped up in stacks on the beach, in readiness for the
boats which he then intended to bring into the bay
12:00.title: The Prince
12:00.author: Niccolò Machiavelli

12:00.quote:
This Persoun him answerede al at oones:
    Thou getest fable noon i-told for me

12:00.quote: Secondly, I say that alle wommen be wikked, and noon good of hem alle
12:00.title: Mr. Standfast
12:00.author: John Buchan

12:00.quote:
For of a thousand men, saith Solomon, I find oon good man; but certes
of alle wommen good womman find I never noon

12:00.author: John Buchan

*CHAPTER IV*

                            *A CROWDED DAY*


After a late breakfast about noon Tex got the gunny sack, threw it over
his shoulder and went to the Mecca, nodding to the proprietor in a
spirit of good-will and cheerfulness

patient, felt he could safely leave him for a few minutes

12:00.quote:
Sunday morning found them quiet; but Sunday noon found them restless and
resentful

12:00.author: H.G. Wells

12:00.quote:
He arrived at the office at
noon, and was sent back over the same road on which he had just come,

consequence to suburban New York killed

noon--he could see that the sun had yet a heavy space to cover before

12:00.quote:
They then sat down at noon to their bread and cheese and, most

12:00.author: Xenophon

12:00.quote:

12:00.quote:
Resumed
my walk, and at about four miles from Tain, crossed the Dornoch

12:00.author: Xenophon

12:00.quote:
After

12:00.author: Xenophon

12:00.quote:
About noon they stopped to allow Jim to rest in the shade of a pretty

"There are bears near by
12:00.title: The House of the Seven Gables

12:00.quote: It is almost noon

12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.title: Rewards and Fairies
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote: It was long past noon when he awoke

Next day, by noon, I was up and dressed, and sat wrapped in a shawl by

I felt it would be

12:00.title: Jane Eyre
12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.quote:

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.quote:
I took no note of the lapse of time—of the change

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.quote:

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.author: Joseph Conrad

12:00.author: H. Rider Haggard

12:00.author: H. Rider Haggard

12:00.quote:
"When the Angelus began to ring at noon, Magnificence."

"Why not before?"

"The captain was undecided

12:00.author: H. Rider Haggard

12:00.quote:
But they must all be back inside the Kasteel precincts
by two hours after noon
12:00.title: Cleopatra
12:00.author: H. Rider Haggard

12:00.quote:
He must have started
well before noon ..
12:00.title: Cleopatra
12:00.author: H. Rider Haggard

12:00.quote:
The proposal has come from the High-Bailiff, at the hour of

12:00.author: H. Rider Haggard

12:00.quote:
Thus, let us

12:00.author: Charles Darwin

12:00.quote:

“Good,” said Comminges

12:00.author: Alexandre Dumas

12:00.author: Alexandre Dumas

12:00.quote:
All three agreed to meet at

12:00.author: Alexandre Dumas

12:00.quote:
At noon they rode into the avenue of

12:00.author: Alexandre Dumas

12:00.quote: Noon came, and afternoon

12:00.title: Martin Eden
12:00.author: Jack London

12:00.quote:

None so gay as she;

12:00.author: L. Frank Baum

Noon whistles been blowin'.”

“All right,” Penrod repeated dully

12:00.quote:
At sight of Marjorie, Penrod Schofield flushed

12:00.author: L. Frank Baum

12:00.quote:
The noon whistles failed to disturb this little Arcady; only the
sound of Mrs

12:00.author: L. Frank Baum

12:00.quote:
Crisparkle—whose fresh nature is by no means insensible to the charms

Nine miles is quite a distance, but we ought to

rock of Alcavella, lying about six miles from St

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

No sea-fog; no

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.quote:
I often walked all day, through the burning noon and the arid

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.quote:
There are human tempers, bland, glowing, and genial, within whose

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.quote:
She, had no business to
lounge away the noon on a sofa

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.quote:
Our way lay through some of the best streets of Villette, streets

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.quote:
When hot noon arrived—for the day turned out as we had anticipated,

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.quote:
He passed quietly, like a shadow sweeping the sky, at
noon

12:00.author: Charlotte Brontë

12:00.quote:

noon, for her walk was a long one

12:00.author: Edgar Rice Burroughs

12:00.quote:

12:00.quote:
I realised that it would enable me to continue working through the noon

On the light of Liberty you saw arise the light of Peace, like

12:00.author: H. Rider Haggard

Thou art so fat-witted with drinking of old sack, and

    noon, that thou hast forgotten to demand that truly which
thou
    wouldest truly know

12:00.quote:

12:00.quote:

“I take what you said to me

I could keep it at school, and
practise at noon a whole hour

12:00.quote:
Then I will take it to
school so that I can practise at noon

arrangements with the superintendent to leave it in his office and

12:00.quote:

12:00.quote: At noon Mrs
12:00.title: Five Children and It

12:00.quote:
It was noon before she finished, and then she packed a
basket of lunch

12:00.quote:
Then a cold lunch at noon, and a three-mile walk at

O’More, would you get off a message at once?”

Every one met the noon boat

See?"

12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
The people who dwell in opposite hemispheres of the earth, and
whose shadows at noon fall in contrary directions
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote: APPARENT NOON
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
Those which are reckoned from noon or midnight of
one natural day, to noon or midnight of another
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
The astronomical day is reckoned from noon to noon, continuously
through the twenty-four hours, like the other days
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
It commences at
noon, twelve hours after the civil day, which itself begins twelve hours
after the nautical day, so that the _noon_ of the civil day, the
_beginning_ of the astronomical day, and the _end_ of the nautical day,
occur at the same moment
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
A cant phrase for taking a glass of grog at
noon, when the day's works are being reduced
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
In sea-journals, the day, or
twenty-four hours, used to terminate at noon, because the ship's
position is then generally determined by observation; but the shore
account of time is now adopted afloat
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
The whole being written by the mate of the watch with chalk,
is rubbed out every day at noon
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
The order of a commander to confirm the time, sunrise, noon,
or sunset, reported to him by the officer of the watch
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote: MEAN NOON
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
The noon of a mean day supposing the year to be divided into
days of equal length
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
This day commences at noon, twelve hours before the civil
day, and ends at noon of the day following
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
A Shakspearian expression for a coast indented with bays;
as in _Henry V._ Bourbon speaks contemptuously of "that nook-shotten
isle of Albion."

NOON
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
By this alone, within three hours on
each side of noon, the longitude, latitude, and magnetic variation of a
position may be determined
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
The reduction of the distances run on each course, corrected
for variation and lee-way, constitutes the traverse table, from which
the reckoning is deduced each day up to noon
12:00.title: A Journey to the Centre of the Earth
12:00.author: Jules Verne

12:00.quote:
Reducing the dead-reckoning and meridian altitudes
to noon of each day

 While hobble-chains and camp-ware

Not premeditated

1853

THE clock has struck noon; ere it thrice tell the hours

And I shall blush deeper with shame-driven blood

Our friend, our guide, our trusted chief,--

`Lo, this request is not but skile, y-wis,            365

1740
               Secoundelich, ther yet devyneth noon

12:00.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

12:00.quote:
`But, sith that thou hast don me this servyse

               So, for the love of god, this grete empryse
               Performe it out; for now is moste nede

12:00.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

12:00.quote:
890
               Ye nece myn, that ring moste han a stoon
               That mighte dede men alyve maken;
               And swich a ring trowe I that ye have noon

12:00.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

12:00.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

12:00.quote:
Out of my woful body harm ther noon is,

12:00.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

12:00.quote:
For ther ben grete clerkes many oon,

12:00.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

12:00.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

12:00.quote:
So though ther nere comfort noon but this,

12:00.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

12:00.quote:

would be at five thousand per cent discount out at nurse making a mud
pie at nine in the morning, and (being inquired for) would go up to
five thousand per cent premium before noon
12:00.title: Our Mutual Friend
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote: I am going straight home, and shall remain at home to-morrow until noon
12:00.title: Our Mutual Friend
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
A twilight calm of happiness then succeeding to their radiant noon, they
remained at peace, until a strange voice in the room startled them both
12:00.title: Our Mutual Friend
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote: The work went on, until the noon-bell rang
12:00.title: The Pickwick Papers
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
Gradgrind, adjusting her shawls after the
affectionate ceremony, ‘I shall be worrying myself, morning, noon, and
night, to know what I am to call him!’

‘Mrs
12:00.title: The Pickwick Papers
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
Now, if you’ll believe me, she hasn’t come out of that house since noon
to-day
12:00.title: The Pickwick Papers
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
You watch for
noon, all of you, and we’ll stand up, and when we can’t cast a shadow
we’ll find that this Grinnage clock is coming mighty close to marking
twelve
12:00.title: The Iliad
12:00.author: Homer

12:00.quote:
TOM RESPECTS THE FLEA


“Noon!” says Tom, and so it was
12:00.title: The Iliad
12:00.author: Homer

12:00.quote:
It
isn't possible that anything has happened to the sun, and
this is twelve at noon!"

The idea being an alarming one, he scrambled out of bed,
and groped his way to the window
12:00.title: A Christmas Carol
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
Toward noon we stumbled upon a well-constructed road running in the
general direction we had been pursuing
12:00.title: Tarzan and the Jewels of Opar
12:00.author: Edgar Rice Burroughs

12:00.quote:
Toward noon we came in touch with the head of the column we had set out
to meet
12:00.title: Tarzan and the Jewels of Opar
12:00.author: Edgar Rice Burroughs

12:00.quote: Noon slumbers
12:00.title: Ulysses
12:00.author: James Joyce

12:00.quote:
A school of turlehide whales stranded in hot noon,
spouting, hobbling in the shallows
12:00.title: Ulysses
12:00.author: James Joyce

12:00.quote: Pan’s hour, the faunal noon
12:00.title: Ulysses
12:00.author: James Joyce

12:00.quote:
Explain that: morning hours, noon, then evening coming on, then
night hours
12:00.title: Ulysses
12:00.author: James Joyce

12:00.quote:
The adiaphane in the noon
of life is an Egypt’s plague which in the nights of prenativity and
postmortemity is their most proper _ubi_ and _quomodo_
12:00.title: Ulysses
12:00.author: James Joyce

12:00.quote: About noon
12:00.title: Ulysses
12:00.author: James Joyce

12:00.quote: The hours of noon follow in amber gold
12:00.title: Ulysses
12:00.author: James Joyce

12:00.quote:
_Balance!_

_(The morning and noon hours waltz in their places, turning, advancing
to each other, shaping their curves, bowing visavis
12:00.title: Ulysses
12:00.author: James Joyce

12:00.quote:
Morning, noon
and twilight hours retreat before them
12:00.title: Ulysses
12:00.author: James Joyce

12:00.quote:
Warblings under the sun, usher’d as now, or at noon, or setting,
  Strains musical flowing through ages, now reaching hither,
  I take to your reckless and composite chords, add to them, and
      cheerfully pass them forward
12:00.title: Leaves of Grass
12:00.author: Walt Whitman

12:00.quote:
FROM NOON TO STARRY NIGHT


Thou Orb Aloft Full-Dazzling

  Thou orb aloft full-dazzling
12:00.title: Leaves of Grass
12:00.author: Walt Whitman

12:00.quote: thou hot October noon
12:00.title: Leaves of Grass
12:00.author: Walt Whitman

12:00.quote:
Flooding with sheeny light the gray beach sand,
  The sibilant near sea with vistas far and foam,
  And tawny streaks and shades and spreading blue;
  O sun of noon refulgent
12:00.title: Leaves of Grass
12:00.author: Walt Whitman

12:00.quote:
I too carol the sun, usher’d or at noon, or as now, setting,
  I too throb to the brain and beauty of the earth and of all the
      growths of the earth,
  I too have felt the resistless call of myself
12:00.title: Leaves of Grass
12:00.author: Walt Whitman

12:00.quote:
You have been with
us, too, some years, and can fairly compare the twilight of rights,
which your race enjoy at the North, with that “noon of night” under
which they labor south of Mason and Dixon’s line
12:00.title: The Pioneers
12:00.author: James Fenimore Cooper

12:00.quote:
He prayed
morning, noon, and night
12:00.title: The Pioneers
12:00.author: James Fenimore Cooper

12:00.quote: 4._ Watered at noon
12:00.title: The Sleeper Awakes
12:00.author: H.G. Wells

12:00.quote: Watered at noon
12:00.title: The Sleeper Awakes
12:00.author: H.G. Wells

12:00.quote:
I once knew of a window-box on a
tin roof on the south side of the house that was watered morning, noon,
and night
12:00.title: The Sleeper Awakes
12:00.author: H.G. Wells

12:00.quote: Other interrogators appeared at noon
12:00.title: The Island of Sheep
12:00.author: John Buchan

12:00.quote: It was nearly noon
12:00.title: The Island of Sheep
12:00.author: John Buchan

12:00.quote: As I have life and honour, there shall he sit till noon
12:00.title: King Lear
12:00.author: William Shakespeare

12:00.quote: Till noon
12:00.title: King Lear
12:00.author: William Shakespeare

12:00.quote: And I’ll go to bed at noon
12:00.title: King Lear
12:00.author: William Shakespeare

12:00.quote: At noon Ovid came home
12:00.title: The Ramayana
12:00.author: Valmiki

12:00.quote:
At noon I gave no orders for a change of course, and the mate’s whiskers
became much concerned and seemed to be offering themselves unduly to my
notice
12:00.title: The Man with Two Left Feet
12:00.author: P.G. Wodehouse

12:00.quote:
The hammock and the carriers were dwarfed by
the great roots and buttresses of the trees to tiny, crawling ants,
and overhead was a narrow strip of blue sky where the sunlight might
be seen, but only at noon did that sunlight reach the roadway below
12:00.title: Danger!
12:00.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

12:00.quote:
But
when they halted again to dine, and for the night (they had not camped
at noon, and lunch had been but a picnic) she laid aside silk trousers
and tinseled satin coat—to her surprise a little regretfully
12:00.title: An Anarchist
12:00.author: Joseph Conrad

12:00.quote:
He
woke up at noon, feeling better, though his head still ached
abominably
12:00.title: The Incredulity of Father Brown
12:00.author: G.K. Chesterton

12:00.quote:
Eldridge passed
till twelve o'clock, when that suspense was reduced to a shocking
certainty, and every spark of hope which till then they had indulged,
was in a moment extinguished
12:00.title: The Wisdom of Father Brown
12:00.author: G.K. Chesterton

12:00.quote:
Having
then been on deck for twice four hours, at eight o’clock in the morning
your _watch-below_ comes round, and you are not liable to duty until
noon
12:00.title: Billy Budd
12:00.author: Herman Melville

12:00.quote:
About noon the next day, the gale so moderated that we shook two reefs
out of the top-sails, set new courses, and stood due east, with the
wind astern
12:00.title: Billy Budd
12:00.author: Herman Melville

12:00.quote:
By noon, he perspired very freely; but then his
cloak attracted all eyes, and that was huge satisfaction
12:00.title: Billy Budd
12:00.author: Herman Melville

12:00.quote: Who ever saw a star when the noon sun was in sight
12:00.title: Billy Budd
12:00.author: Herman Melville

12:00.quote:
Come on, Rainbow and Cross!”

But the wind was long languid and faint, not yet recovered from its
night’s dissipation ashore, and noon advanced, with the Sugar-Loaf
pinnacle in sight
12:00.title: Billy Budd
12:00.author: Herman Melville

12:00.quote:
It was just eight bells—noon, and springing from my white
jacket, which I had spread between the guns for a bed on the main-deck,
I ran up the ladders, and, as usual, seized hold of the main-brace,
which fifty hands were streaming along forward
12:00.title: Billy Budd
12:00.author: Herman Melville

12:00.quote:
It was, therefore, a subterranean vault, into which scarce a ray
of heaven’s glad light ever penetrated, even at noon
12:00.title: Billy Budd
12:00.author: Herman Melville

12:00.quote:
Jack Hubert said this noon that May Randall was
asking for me before I met him
12:00.title: What Katy Did
12:00.author: Susan Coolidge

12:00.quote:
“While we wash dishes and clear camp the boys can go and bring in
fire-wood for this noon
12:00.title: What Katy Did
12:00.author: Susan Coolidge

12:00.quote:
By noon the out-of-doors proved a veritable “wet
blanket” on the spirits of the Woodcrafters and they gathered
disconsolately in the gymnasium at three o’clock, wishing they lived in
Egypt at the dry season of the year
12:00.title: What Katy Did
12:00.author: Susan Coolidge

12:00.quote:
If it does, the leaf will
immediately fall off.”

So much time had been taken by the collecting and descriptions of
articles made of birch bark, that it was noon before anyone dreamed it
was more than ten o’clock
12:00.title: What Katy Did
12:00.author: Susan Coolidge

12:00.quote:
That noon, Miss
Miller sent word to each girl that an important letter would be
considered at a special meeting in the gymnasium directly after school
in the afternoon
12:00.title: What Katy Did
12:00.author: Susan Coolidge

12:00.quote:
Early Friday morning a very light snow began falling,
but grew heavier until noon, when great gusts of snow were swept across
the valley at every fresh hurricane of wind
12:00.title: What Katy Did
12:00.author: Susan Coolidge

12:00.quote:
We’ll have it instead of lettuce this noon.”

Two of the girls preferred to help May gather cress as they thought they
had enough reed and rush for a mat, so by the time the cutting was done,
the three girls had a large basketful of water-cress
12:00.title: What Katy Did
12:00.author: Susan Coolidge

12:00.quote:
Then the Doctor telephoned just before noon and told
the Guide that the friends and families of Wako Tribe were coming down
to hold a Council on the afternoon of the Fourth
12:00.title: What Katy Did
12:00.author: Susan Coolidge

12:00.quote:
The girls expected the visitors about noon, but it was almost two
o’clock before a maddening sound reached them
12:00.title: What Katy Did
12:00.author: Susan Coolidge

12:00.quote:
At the luncheon that noon,
plans were made for the siding and roofing the cabin
12:00.title: What Katy Did
12:00.author: Susan Coolidge

12:00.quote: This work was great fun and was finished by noon
12:00.title: What Katy Did
12:00.author: Susan Coolidge

12:00.quote:
Nebsecht laughed too, and said, "Now I know why my clothes were so heavy,
and felt so intolerably hot at noon
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
Only Paaker and Nefert need go with me."

The princess hastened forward into the gorge, which was oppressive with
the noon-tide heat; but she moderated her steps as soon as she observed
that the frailer Nefert found it difficult to follow her
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
Her face was red and white by
turns, as light and shade chase each other on the ground when at noon-day
a palm-grove is stirred by a storm
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
It was noon: the rays of the sun found no way into the narrow shady
streets of the city of Thebes, but they blazed with scorching heat on the
broad dyke-road which led to the king's castle, and which at this hour
was usually almost deserted
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
The old paraschites Pinem had joined with his fellows in the lamentation
for the sacred beasts, and was now sitting on the hard pavement of the
dissecting room to eat his morsel of food--for it was noon
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
At last he tasted the meat, and thought of many former noon-day meals,
and how he had often found a flower in the satchel, that Uarda had placed
there to please him, with the bread
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
"I fished him up with the bucket, and laid him to dry in the sun; but he
had been tasting all sorts of medicines, and he died at noon
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
Good night, leave
me; Melitta!"

At noon on the following day, the same boat, which, the evening before,
had carried the Athenian and the Spartan, stopped once more before
Rhodopis' garden
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
At noon on the following clay, Bartja, accompanied by his friends and a
troop of attendants, started on horseback for the frontier
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
"Towards noon I shall
come to teach you, and we can talk sometimes about Egypt and your loved
ones there, but always in Persian
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
It is very near dawn now, and at noon she shall be
flogged through the streets
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
Give little Parmys a thousand kisses from me, and tell Melitta
never to take her out at noon
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
Just at the door she met Irene, who told her that the singing-practice
was put off, on account of the procession which was fixed for four hours
after noon
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
The westwind, which had
begun to blow even at noon, now rose higher, and seemed to pursue her
with its hot breath and the clouds of sand it carried with it from the
desert
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
Toward sunrise, or at latest
by the noon-tide hour, the tribes will tarry to rest at Succoth
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
These made a deep impression on my soul and, whenever I was
alone in the evening, or at noon-day when the shepherds and flocks were
far away in the fields, I repeated these songs or composed new ones, most
of which were hymns in praise of the deity
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
Noon came, the afternoon passed away,
evening deepened into night, and morning returned, yet I still waited for
the guest
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
At noon,
overwhelmed by fatigue, he had fallen asleep under the shade of a
sycamore, and when he awoke the sun was near its setting
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
If they had only let us start before noon, and not
waited until the omen had been consulted and Anna had been installed with
all due solemnity in Bai's place, it would have been easy work, and we
should have caught them like a flock of quail
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote: We shall reach our destination at noon
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
At noon the people were permitted to rest, but there was not a hand's
breadth of shade where they sought repose
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
At noon the heat could not fail to be scorching again between the bare
precipices which in many places jutted very near one another; but the
coolness of the morning still lingered
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
How the noon-tide heat must
burden those who were fighting and struggling below; how the bleeding
wounds of those who had fallen in the dust must burn
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
If he should try her at noon and find her guilty, there was
nothing to prevent him from compelling her to drink the poisoned cup or
having her strangled before evening
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
It
was long after noon when the litter was again borne to Lochias
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
"Now till noon I must work
with Phlegon and Titianus, whom I am expecting, and then perhaps we may
find something to laugh at
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
When will the
prefect's wife fetch you?"

"To-morrow about noon."

"Then early to-morrow buy a nice new dress."

"Will there not be enough for a new bracelet too?" asked Arsinoe,
coaxingly
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
After such a morning what could noon and evening be to him
without her
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
I cannot change your hearts--but the
wife of my brother's son, the daughter of Ben Akiba, must be a daughter
of our people, morning, noon, and night
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
And Hermas
did not wrench himself from her white arms, as he had torn himself from
hers that noon by the spring-torn himself away never to return
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
The
young man had arrived about noon with the slaves he had just procured,
had learned all that had happened in his absence, and had silently
withdrawn into his own room after supper was ended
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
At noon of the following day the senator went to the women's room, and
while he was still on the threshold, he asked his wife--who was busy at
the loom:

"Where is Polykarp
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
After sunrise he refreshed
himself with a morsel of food, and then hurried on again, not heeding the
heat of noon, nor that of the soft sand in which his foot sank as he
followed the line of the sea-coast
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
Since his disappearance Miriam had incessantly hovered round Stephanus'
dwelling, and had fetched fresh water for the old man every morning, noon
and evening, even after a new nurse, who was clumsier and more peevish,
had taken Paulus' place
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
Even during
the hottest noon she would sit in the sun, with a large green umbrella to
shade her keen eyes, and those who desired to speak with her might find
shade as best they could
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
Our houses are within a stone's throw, and yet in a whole day,
from noon till noon, so old a friend could not find a few minutes to
deliver the letters entrusted to him, or to call upon such near neighbors
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
It was long past noon when
a diversion took place which served at any rate to interest and amuse the
crying child
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
The general confusion was
distracting; as the sun rose, the anguish, physical and mental, of the
whole family greatly increased, and by noon had reached an appalling
pitch
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
Towards noon she dismissed the Magian and allowed herself a short
interval of rest and sleep; but as soon as she woke she collected her
wits, and set to work again with fresh zeal and diligence
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote: A little before noon Hermon came to see her
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
When, soon after noon, the lessee of the royal bank appeared on the ship
to offer him as many drachmae or talents as he might need for present
use, he asked for a considerable sum to purchase a larger death-offering
for his murdered friend
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
He joined the ladies before noon, and his newly awakened feeling of joy
beamed upon them scarcely less radiantly than yesterday
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
The feast lasted
until early morning, but toward noon Hermon again appeared in his uncle's
house, and met Daphne full of joyous confidence, as if he were completely
transformed
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
At noon Hanno was about to get into a boat to go to her father's ship,
and she insisted upon accompanying him
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
A galley ready to weigh anchor was constantly at the disposal of
the commandant of the fortress, and the next noon the noble pair, with
Hermon and his faithful Bias, went on board the Galatea
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote: After noon Eumedes could at last devote himself to his young friend
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
He told her that the Nabathaean who had brought the rumor that had
excited her hopes, was not unwilling to follow up the trace he had found,
but he would not wait beyond noon the next day and had tried to bid for
high terms
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
"As it is not yet two hours after noon, send all your men out to search
for him and deliver him up
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
If I find you under this roof
to-morrow at noon, you thankless, wicked girl, I will have you turned out
into the streets by the guard
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
In the neat rooms which Rufinus' wife had made ready for her sick guests
perfect peace reigned, and it was noon
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
By about two hours after noon Paula's restlessness had increased so much
that now and then she wandered out of the sick-room, which looked over
the garden, to watch the Nile-quay from the window of the anteroom; for
he might arrive by either way
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
It was three hours past noon, and she had returned to the sick-room, when
she thought that she heard hoofs in the garden and hurried to the window
once more
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
But, if you
have read these lines, I will make my appearance to-morrow, at two hours
after noon, with Nilus to explain to the others the arrangement of which
I have spoken
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
More than this
the widow did not require of her, and as the girl flew up the stairs to
her room she was thinking: "Orion will be coming directly: it still wants
fully two hours of noon, and if he stays there half an hour that will be
more than enough
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
It was now within three-quarters of an hour of noon, and in that house
all was as still as before; the Patriarch, however, might be expected to
be punctual, and she had done nothing towards dressing but putting on
those gilt sandals
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
The waiting-woman was ordered to come for her at noon with
the flowers for the Patriarch, and, in a quarter of an hour after leaving
her lurking place, she was back there again
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
It must be very near noon if not already past; she dusted her sandals and
tidied her curly hair, picking out the dry leaves and not noticing that
at the same time a rose fell out on the ground
12:00.title: A Discourse on Inequality
12:00.author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

12:00.quote:
"That is why Anubis was free at noon."

12:00.quote: It was noon when we got back

As it was noon, and high time to eat something, we lit a fire a little

12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote: It was noon when we mounted our horses and rode down the stony incline

12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
About noon we had a prospect of a deep rocky valley, on whose

12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

We crossed the Leone about noon, at the same pretty spot as when we

12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

Our path ran at a rather great

We rode down into the valley, following a very deeply-trodden buffalo

12:00.title: Many Inventions

12:00.quote: It was near noon, and I had generally walked fast

12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
Hence I marched due west, and

12:00.quote:
Toward noon, however, the road became fatiguing, as we had
to climb rather large hills that jutted out from the mountain chain on

12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
On the other side of them,
which we reached about noon, we came to another small stream, on whose
banks we saw a number of peeled trees, and also found here a beaver
lodge
12:00.title: Many Inventions
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
About noon we reached
a hollow between two ranges of hills, where we found fresh grass and a
stream whose banks were covered with low bushes
12:00.title: Many Inventions
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
A few days after we were surprised by
two men, as we were letting our horses graze at noon
12:00.title: Many Inventions
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
About noon we
were scaling a height when suddenly a mighty condor spread out its
enormous wings with a loud yell, and rose from a rock with a great
effort, and we saw a mountain sheep hanging in its claws

12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
In time we got everything in order
again, and about noon we saw our Indians coming down the valley and
driving our animals before them, which they had found a long way in the

12:00.title: Many Inventions
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
It
was nearly noon when we struck camp and marched up the river
12:00.title: Many Inventions
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
At length, toward noon, wood rose
again from the barren surface
12:00.title: Many Inventions
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
It was hardly noon when we started again and spurred our horses
on toward the southern prairie
12:00.title: Many Inventions
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
We lay in the shade
of the closely-growing elms and poplars, and were drinking coffee at
noon, as Tiger had not yet returned, when we suddenly heard the

12:00.title: Many Inventions
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
We started very early, rode till far into the evening, and
rested, when we could manage it, at noon in some shadow, for the heat

12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
We continued our journey for about a week, and crossed a number of small

rivulet, on whose shady bank we resolved to rest

So he went on a while betwixt the trees and the thickets, till it was a
little past noon
12:00.title: The Man Who Was Thursday

12:00.quote:
CHAPTER 2

They Break Their Fast in the Wildwood


Now when it was hard on noon, and they had lain long in that grassy
place, Ralph rose up and stood upon his feet, and made as one
listening
12:00.title: The Man Who Was Thursday

12:00.quote:

serving men busied them about his dinner, and David went with them
12:00.title: The Man Who Was Thursday
12:00.author: G.K. Chesterton

12:00.quote:
Thus they rode the down country, till at last, two hours before noon,
coming over the brow of a long down, they had before them a shallow
dale, pleasanter than aught they had yet seen
12:00.title: The Man Who Was Thursday
12:00.author: G.K. Chesterton

12:00.quote:
About two hours before noon they got to horse again, and, being no more
encumbered with the wains and the beasts, rode at a good pace
12:00.title: The Man Who Was Thursday
12:00.author: G.K. Chesterton

12:00.quote:
Then again they rested and let

place till it was two hours after noon
12:00.title: The Man Who Was Thursday
12:00.author: G.K. Chesterton

12:00.quote:
But on the third day, somewhat after noon, when they were come up above
the tilled upland and the land was rough and the ways steep, there lay
before them a dark wood swallowing up the road
12:00.title: The Man Who Was Thursday
12:00.author: G.K. Chesterton

12:00.quote:
And now we were best get to horse; for what with
meat and minstrelsy, we have worn away the day till it wants but a
little of noon
12:00.title: The Man Who Was Thursday
12:00.author: G.K. Chesterton

12:00.quote:
So they rode off all of them toward Bear Castle, and shortly to
say it, came within sight of its rampart two hours before noon
12:00.title: The Man Who Was Thursday
12:00.author: G.K. Chesterton

12:00.quote: Now amidst all these deeds it yet lacked an hour of noon

So busy all the morning and at noon to Cocke, and
dined there
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon to dinner, and after
some discourse of musique, he and I to the office awhile, and he to get
Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, and then to the office
again, leaving Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: At noon with him to dinner at Boreman’s, where Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Batten comes in by and by, and so staying till noon,
and there being a great deal of company there, Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
It being a fast day, all people were
at church and the office quiett; so I did much business, and at noon
adventured to my old lodging, and there eat, but am not yet well
satisfied, not seeing of Christopher, though they say he is abroad
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
I up and to the office (leaving my wife in bed) and there till
noon, then to dinner and back again to the office, my wife going to
Woolwich again, and I staying very late at my office, and so home to
bed
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Up, and to my office, where busy all the morning, and at noon to
Captain Cocke’s to dinner as we had appointed in order to settle our
business of accounts
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Up and all the morning at the office, busy, and at noon to the
King’s Head taverne, where all the Trinity House dined to-day, to choose
a new Master in the room of Hurlestone, that is dead, and Captain Crispe
is chosen
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Up, and to the office, where all the morning doing business, and
at noon home to dinner and quickly back again to the office, where very
busy all the evening and late sent a long discourse to Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon comes Sir Thomas
Allen, and I made him dine with me, and very friendly he is, and a good
man, I think, but one that professes he loves to get and to save
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Dined with my wife at
noon and took leave of her, she being to go to London, as I said, for
altogether, and I to the office, busy till past one in the morning
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon empty, yet without stomach to dinner, having
spoiled myself with fasting yesterday, and so filled with wind
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon late to
dinner, and after dinner spent till night with Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, only
eating a bit, and with much kindness taking leave of Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Warren in the business of the insurance as I desired,
and ended some other businesses of his, and so at noon I to London,
but the ‘Change was done before I got thither, so I to the Pope’s Head
Taverne, and there find Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: At noon to dinner, Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon by agreement
comes Hatcham Pepys to dine with me
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon all of us dined at Captain
Cocke’s at a good chine of beef, and other good meat; but, being all
frost-bitten, was most of it unroast; but very merry, and a good dish of
fowle we dressed ourselves
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon comes
Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Up and to the office, at noon home to dinner, and all the
afternoon to my accounts again, and there find myself, to my great joy,
a great deal worth above L4000, for which the Lord be praised
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, where uncle Thomas
with me, and in comes Pierce lately come from Oxford, and Ferrers
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
So away back again to the office, and at noon to
dinner all of us by invitation to Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon eat the second of the two cygnets
Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Busy all the morning in my chamber in my old cloth suit, while my
usuall one is to my taylor’s to mend, which I had at noon again, and an
answer to a letter I had sent this morning to Mrs
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
However, by noon they
come, and a dinner we had, and Kate Joyce comes to see us, with whom
very merry
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon to dinner, and then to the office again, late, and
so to supper and to bed
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Lay almost till noon merrily and with pleasure
talking with my wife in bed
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon my Lord Bruncker did come, but left the keys of the chests
we should open, at Sir G
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: Up and to the office, at noon home to dinner
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon after a bit of dinner back
to the office and there fitting myself in all points to give an account
to the Duke and Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon to the ‘Change,
expecting to have received from Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: At noon, full of business, to dinner
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon to the ‘Change, and
thence after business dined at the Sheriffe’s [Hooker], being carried by
Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon to Starky’s, a great cooke in Austin Friars,
invited by Colonell Atkins, and a good dinner for Colonell Norwood
and his friends, among others Sir Edward Spragg and others, but ill
attendance
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon comes my uncle Wight to dinner, and brings with
him Mrs
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: So at noon by coach to St
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Evelyn’s
proposition about publique Infirmarys was read and agreed on, he being
there: and at noon I took him home to dinner, being desirous of keeping
my acquaintance with him; and a most excellent humoured man I still find
him, and mighty knowing
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to
dinner and thence by coach with my wife for ayre principally for her
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
I set them down at
the ‘Change and I home to the office, and at noon dined at home and to
the office again
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon late to dinner,
my wife gone out to Hales’s about her picture, and, after dinner, I
after her, and do mightily like her picture, and think it will be as
good as my Lady Peters’s
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Up, and to the office and there all the morning sitting and
at noon to dinner with my Lord Bruncker, Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
All the morning at the office, at noon to the Old James, being sent
for, and there dined with Sir William Rider, Cutler, and others, to make
an end with two Scots Maisters about the freight of two ships of my Lord
Rutherford’s
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
To the ‘Change at
noon and so home to dinner
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Then to the
office and there till noon and so home to dinner and to the office again
till night
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: Up, and to the office, and there busy sitting till noon
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Coventry and so home and to church, and at noon dined and then to
my chamber, where with great pleasure about one business or other till
late, and so to supper and to bed
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
All the news now is, that Sir
Jeremy Smith is at Cales--[Cadiz]--with his fleete, and Mings in the
Elve.--[Elbe]--The King is come this noon to towne from Audly End, with
the Duke of Yorke and a fine train of gentlemen
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon to dinner, and then
to the office again, where mighty business, doing a great deale till
midnight and then home to supper and to bed
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner and presently with my wife out
to Hales’s, where I am still infinitely pleased with my wife’s picture
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined in
haste, and so my wife, Mrs
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon my wife being gone
to her father’s I dined with Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to
dinner, where Anthony Joyce, and I did give my final answer, I would
give but L500 with my sister, and did show him the good offer made us
in the country, to which I did now more and more incline, and intend to
pursue that
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon to dinner, where my
wife’s brother, whom I sent for to offer making him a Muster-Master and
send to sea, which the poore man likes well of and will go, and it will
be a good preferment to him, only hazardous
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: At noon dined at home, Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined and then out to
Lumbard Streete, to look after the getting of some money that is lodged
there of mine in Viner’s hands, I having no mind to have it lie there
longer
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon to dinner, and thence
to the office and did my business there as soon as I could, and then
home and to my accounts, where very late at them, but, Lord
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon by coach home, and
there by invitation met my uncle and aunt Wight and their cozen Mary,
and dined with me and very merry
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, and there my brother
Balty dined with me and my wife, who is become a good serious man, and
I hope to do him good being sending him a Muster-Master on one of the
squadrons of the fleete
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
All the morning upon business
at the office, and at noon dined, and Mrs
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: So up to the office and there till noon
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
To the office
and there sat till noon, and then home and dined, and to the office
again all the afternoon, where we sat all, the first time of our
resolution to sit both forenoons and afternoons
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
This noon Bagwell’s wife come to me to the office, after her
being long at Portsmouth
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined at home
and so to my office again, and taking a turne in the garden my Lady Pen
comes to me and takes me into her house, where I find her daughter and a
pretty lady of her acquaintance, one Mrs
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined at home and Creed with me, then parted, and I
to the office, and anon called thence by Sir H
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined alone, the
girl Mercer taking physique can eat nothing, and W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined at
home, my brother Balty with me, who is fitting himself to go to sea
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon
dined with Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, and
in the afternoon to my office again, where very busy all the afternoon
and particularly about fitting of Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon to the ‘Change a little, and there bespoke some maps to
hang in my new roome (my boy’s roome) which will be very-pretty
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: At noon dined at home
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined alone, my wife
gone abroad to conclude about her necklace of pearle
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined at home, my
wife’s cheek bad still
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to
dinner and there busy all the afternoon till past six o’clock, and then
abroad with my wife by coach, who is now at great ease, her cheeke being
broke inward
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home, where I find my wife troubled
still at my checking her last night in the coach in her long stories out
of Grand Cyrus, which she would tell, though nothing to the purpose, nor
in any good manner
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: At noon took Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined
mighty nobly, ourselves alone
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined at home, and after dinner
comes in my wife’s brother Balty and his wife, he being stepped ashore
from the fleete for a day or two
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, Balty being gone back to sea and his
wife dining with us, whom afterward my wife carried home
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon rose in the pleasantest
humour I have seen Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined
at home
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
However,
at noon I did, upon a small invitation of Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
By and by
toward noon word is brought me that my father and my sister are come
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon I and my father, wife and
sister, dined at Aunt Wight’s here hard by at Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
So home
after church time to dinner, and after dinner my father, wife, sister,
and Mercer by water to Woolwich, while I walked by land, and saw the
Exchange as full of people, and hath been all this noon as of any other
day, only for newes
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, where my cozen
Joyces, both of them, they and their wives and little Will, come by
invitation to dinner to me, and I had a good dinner for them; but, Lord
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
He tells me further, how the Duke of Yorke is wholly given up
to his new mistresse, my Lady Denham, going at noon-day with all his
gentlemen with him to visit her in Scotland Yard; she declaring she will
not be his mistresse, as Mrs
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
He
gone, at noon I home to dinner, and after dinner my father and wife out
to the painter’s to sit again, and I, with my Lady Pen and her daughter,
to see Harman; whom we find lame in bed
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon to
dinner, and then to White Hall in hopes of a meeting of Tangier about
Yeabsly’s business, but it could not be obtained, Sir G
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon
dined at home, and thence with my wife and father to Hales’s, and there
looked only on my father’s picture (which is mighty like); and so away
to White Hall to a committee for Tangier, where the Duke of York was,
and Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner and then down
to Woolwich and Deptford to look after things, my head akeing from
the multitude of businesses I had in my head yesterday in settling
my accounts
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, my father,
sister, and wife dining at Sarah Giles’s, poor woman, where I should
have been, but my pride would not suffer me
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Home at noon to dinner, and what with the
going away of my father today and the losse of Mercer, I after dinner
went up to my chamber and there could have cried to myself, had not
people come to me about business
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon, without staying to
eat my dinner, I down by water to Deptford, and there coming find Sir
W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined, having first been down at Deptford and
did a little business there and back again
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Pen to towne, which I
little expected, having invited my Lady and her daughter Pegg to dine
with me to-day; which at noon they did, and Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Up and to the office, where we sat all the morning busy, then at
noon dined and Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: At noon W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Lay sleepy in bed till 8 in the morning, then up and to the
office, where till about noon, then out to the ‘Change and several
places, and so home to dinner
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
So to the office
and at noon home to dinner, and then sent for young Michell and employed
him all the afternoon about weighing and shipping off of the corke,
having by this means an opportunity of getting him 30 or 40s
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: So at noon home to dinner, Balty and his wife with us
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon
walked in the garden with Commissioner Pett (newly come to towne), who
tells me how infinite the disorders are among the commanders and all
officers of the fleete
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined at
home: Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon dined at
home and then to the office again, and there walking in the garden with
Captain Cocke till 5 o’clock
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Here we sat and at noon to dinner to the Pope’s Head, where
my Lord Bruncker and his mistresse dined and Commissioner Pett, Dr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Towards
noon before sermon was done at church comes newes by a letter to Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner and
there did practise with Mercer one of my new tunes that I have got Dr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Batten, I was obliged to tell him it was an untruth, which
did displease him mightily, and parted at noon very angry with me
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Up, and to the office, where all the morning, and, at noon
to dinner, and Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, and then to the office
again, being mightily pleased with a Virgin’s head that my wife is now
doing of
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home
to dinner, where mighty pleased at my wife’s beginnings of a little
Virgin’s head
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home, and there dined with
me my Lady Pen only and W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
All the morning at my office; then to the Exchange (with my Lord
Bruncker in his coach) at noon, but it was only to avoid Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
So
at noon to dinner, mightily pleased with my wife’s picture that she is
upon
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon I, with my wife and Mercer, to Philpott Lane, a great
cook’s shop, to the wedding of Mr
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, and then the boy and I to the office, and there
he read while I writ it fair, which done I sent it to Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon, with my wife, against her
will, all undressed and dirty, dined at Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon after
dinner I sent for Harry, and he tells me it is so, and brought me by and
by my hamper of books to my great joy, with the same books I missed, and
three more great ones, and no more
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: At noon with it to Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: At noon Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Thence
home, about noon, to dinner
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
Towards noon, by water to Westminster Hall, and there by
several hear that the Parliament do resolve to do something to retrench
Sir G
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home, and my uncle Thomas was there, and dined with my
brother and I (my father and I were gone abroad), and then to the office
again in the afternoon, and there close all day long, and did much
business
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, and to the office again,
after hearing my brother play a little upon the Lyra viall, which he do
so as to show that he hath a love to musique and a spirit for it, which
I am well pleased with
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to dinner, alone with my brother, with whom I
had now the first private talke I have had, and find he hath
preached but twice in his life
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: At noon with Lord Bruncker to St
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote: At noon Sir W
12:00.title: Ecce Homo
12:00.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

12:00.quote:
At noon home to
dinner, where the two Mrs
12:00.title: Ecce Homo

12:00.quote:
