12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
The
Wind held thus in the same Quarter above two Days, but on the
third about Noon it chang'd, and on the 5th and 6th we had very
bad Weather, so that we were in some Pain to think how the honest
Lads far'd
12:00.title: Wee Willie Winkie
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
In the mean time, we did not hear the least Word of
the Enemy for 8 Months together, so, that we scarce thought any
more of the Scoundrels 'till one _Sunday_ at Noon, when the
Centinel alarm'd us, just as we were at Dinner
12:00.title: Wee Willie Winkie
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
The Wind blew a little fresh, and as it was not yet Noon, we had
Hopes of its coming up with us before Night, since it coasted
along the Shore
12:00.title: Wee Willie Winkie
12:00.author: Rudyard Kipling

12:00.quote:
Add to all this, Cedric had fasted since noon, and his
usual supper hour was long past, a cause of irritation common to
country squires, both in ancient and modern times
12:00.title: Jungle Tales of Tarzan
12:00.author: Edgar Rice Burroughs

12:00.quote:
He’s expected at noon, and no wight till he comes
May profane the great chair, or the porridge of plums
For the best of the cheer, and the seat by the fire,
Is the undenied right of the Barefooted Friar
12:00.title: Jungle Tales of Tarzan
12:00.author: Edgar Rice Burroughs

12:00.quote:
At noon, upon the motion of Athelstane, the travellers paused in a
woodland shade by a fountain, to repose their horses and partake of
some provisions, with which the hospitable Abbot had loaded a sumpter
mule
12:00.title: Jungle Tales of Tarzan
12:00.author: Edgar Rice Burroughs

12:00.quote:
It was about the hour of noon, therefore, when De Bracy, for whose
advantage the expedition had been first planned, appeared to prosecute
his views upon the hand and possessions of the Lady Rowena
12:00.title: Jungle Tales of Tarzan
12:00.author: Edgar Rice Burroughs

12:00.quote: “Away, then,” said Mont-Fitchet; “at noon the affair will proceed
12:00.title: Jungle Tales of Tarzan
12:00.author: Edgar Rice Burroughs

12:00.quote:
I am unwilling to quit these chromatic phenomena without referring to
a source of colour which has often come before me of late in the blue
of your skies at noon, and the deep crimson of your horizon after the
set of sun
12:00.title: Beowulf
12:00.author: Unknown

12:00.quote:
Thus, while the reflected
light gives us, at noon, the deep azure of the Alpine skies, the
transmitted light gives us, at sunset, the warm crimson of the Alpine
snows
12:00.title: Beowulf
12:00.author: Unknown

12:00.quote:
Towards noon he rose, cut
himself food in the pantry, ate it with his head dropped, then pulled
on his boots, and went out, to return at three o’clock slightly tipsy
and relieved; then once more straight to bed
12:00.title: Sons and Lovers
12:00.author: D.H. Lawrence

12:00.quote:
Sunday was the same: bed till noon, the Palmerston Arms till 2.30,
dinner, and bed; scarcely a word spoken
12:00.title: Sons and Lovers
12:00.author: D.H. Lawrence

12:00.quote: It was nearly noon when I arrived at the top of the ascent
12:00.title: Frankenstein
12:00.author: Mary Shelley

12:00.quote:
“The old man, leaning on his son, walked each day at noon, when it did
not rain, as I found it was called when the heavens poured forth its
waters
12:00.title: Frankenstein
12:00.author: Mary Shelley

12:00.quote:
When it became noon, and the
sun rose higher, I lay down on the grass and was overpowered by a deep
sleep
12:00.title: Frankenstein
12:00.author: Mary Shelley

12:00.quote:
PROEM

     I LOVE the old melodious lays
     Which softly melt the ages through,
     The songs of Spenser's golden days,
     Arcadian Sidney's silvery phrase,
     Sprinkling our noon of time with freshest morning dew
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
O'er the heaped drifts of winter's moon
     Her snow-shoes tracked the hunter's way;
     And dazzling in the summer noon
     The blade of her light oar threw off its shower
     of spray
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Even the same
     Old prayer with which, for half a score of years,
     Morning, and noon, and evening, lip and heart
     Had groaned: "Have pity upon me, Lord
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
A sudden light,
     Like the first ray which fell on chaos, clove
     Apart the shadow wherein he had walked
     Darkly at noon
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
O'er went wheel and reel together,
     Little cared the owner whither;
     Heart of lead is heart of feather,
     Noon of night is noon of day
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
"On his little grave I lay;
     Three times went and came the day,
     Thrice above me blazed the noon,
     Thrice upon me wept the moon
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
The locust by the wall
     Stabs the noon-silence with his sharp alarm
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
At high noon on the Merrimac
     The ancient ferryman
     Forgot, at times, his idle oars,
     So fair a freight to scan
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Bland as the morning breath of June
     The southwest breezes play;
     And, through its haze, the winter noon
     Seems warm as summer's day
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote: NOON
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
It knew the glow of eventide,
     The sunrise and the noon,
     And glorified and sanctified
     It slept beneath the moon
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
God's angels come not as of old
     The Syrian shepherds knew them;
     In reddening dawns, in sunset gold,
     And warm noon lights I view them
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Suddenly, a flaw

     Of chill wind menaced; then a strong blast beat
     Down the long valley's murmuring pines, and woke
     The noon-dream of the sleeping lake, and broke
     Its smooth steel mirror at the mountains' feet
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Talk not of sad November, when a day
     Of warm, glad sunshine fills the sky of noon,
     And a wind, borrowed from some morn of June,
     Stirs the brown grasses and the leafless spray
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
The sun that brief December day
     Rose cheerless over hills of gray,
     And, darkly circled, gave at noon
     A sadder light than waning moon
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
And Bethany's palm-trees in beauty still throw
     Their shadows at noon on the ruins below;
     But where are the sisters who hastened to greet
     The lowly Redeemer, and sit at His feet
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Before me, in a vision, rose
     The hosts of Israel's scornful foes,--
     Rank over rank, helm, shield, and spear,
     Glittered in noon's hot atmosphere
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
A fountain's pine-hung slope his seat,
     And lotus-twined his silent feet,
     Whence, piercing heaven, with screened sight,
     He sees at noon the stars, whose light
     Shall glorify the coining night
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Our faith and sight
     Thy presence maketh one
     As through transfigured clouds of white
     We trace the noon-day sun
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Still linger in our noon of time
     And on our Saxon tongue
     The echoes of the home-born hymns
     The Aryan mothers sung
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
At midnight, crow of cock, or noon,
     He cometh sure, He cometh soon
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
at dawn or noon
     Or set of sun, He cometh soon
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
There, safe from sin and the sorrow it brings,
     They sing their grateful psalms,
     And rest, at noon, by the wells of God,
     In the shade of His holy palms
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
WITH a cold and wintry noon-light
     On its roofs and steeples shed,
     Shadows weaving with the sunlight
     From the gray sky overhead,
     Broadly, vaguely, all around me, lies the half-built
     town outspread
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Lord of peoples, lord of lands,
     Look across these shining sands,
     Through the furnace of the noon,
     Through the white light of the moon
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
BEAMS of noon, like burning lances, through the
     tree-tops flash and glisten,
     As she stands before her lover, with raised face to
     look and listen
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
"They have sworn to wait our coming till the night
     has passed its noon,
     And the gray and darkening waters roll above the
     sunken moon!"

     Oh, the blessed hope of freedom
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Down on my native hills of June,
     And home's green quiet, hiding all,
     Fell sudden darkness like the fall
     Of midnight upon noon
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
MY ear is full of summer sounds,
     Of summer sights my languid eye;
     Beyond the dusty village bounds
     I loiter in my daily rounds,
     And in the noon-time shadows lie
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Forty flags with their silver stars,
     Forty flags with their crimson bars,

     Flapped in the morning wind: the sun
     Of noon looked down, and saw not one
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
All through the long, bright days of June
     Its leaves grew green and fair,
     And waved in hot midsummer's noon
     Its soft and yellow hair
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
God save the land
     A careless hand
     May shake or swerve ere morrow's noon
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
At last, our short noon-shadows bid
     The top-stone, bare and brown,
     From whence, like Gizeh's pyramid,
     The rough mass slanted down
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Some die too late and some too soon,
     At early morning, heat of noon,
     Or the chill evening twilight
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
"As waves in stillest waters,
     As stars in noonday skies,
     All that wakes to noble action
     In his noon of calmness lies
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
o'er no sweeter lake
     Shall morning break or noon-cloud sail,--
     No fairer face than thine shall take
     The sunset's golden veil
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
In love, let us trust, they were summoned so soon
     rom the morning of life, while we toil through its noon;
     They were frail like ourselves, they had needs like our own,
     And they rest as we rest in God's mercy alone
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Hers is the sober summer noon
     Contrasted with your morn of spring,
     The waning with the waxing moon,
     The folded with the outspread wing
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
Our toil is sweet with thankfulness,
     Our burden is our boon;
     The curse of Earth's gray morning is
     The blessing of its noon
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
So might I yesterday have sung;
     To-day, in bleak December's noon,
     Come sweetest fragrance, shapes, and hues,
     The rosy wealth of June
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
The morning's promise noon and eve fulfilled
     In warm, soft sky and landscape hazy-hilled
     And sunset fair as they;
     A sweet reminder of His holiest time,
     A summer-miracle in our winter clime,
     God gave a perfect day
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
It being now near noon, we crossed over the
river, to where was a sweet spring of water, very clear and bright,
running out upon the green bank
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
We reached Hampton about one hour before noon; and riding up the road
towards the meeting-house, to my great joy, Uncle Rawson, who had
business with the Commissioners then sitting, came out to meet me,
bidding me go on to Mr
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
The next day we got to the Plantations; and about noon, from the top of
a hill, Mr
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
"But in slumber our spirits at least shall commune,
          We will meet as of old in the visions of sleep,
          In dreams which call back early days, when at noon
          We stole to the shade of the palm-tree to weep
12:00.title: The Castle of Otranto
12:00.author: Horace Walpole

12:00.quote:
A small timber-yard still exists, however,
at the back of the house, and last night, about twelve o'clock, an alarm
was given that one of the stacks was on fire
12:00.title: The Valley of Fear
12:00.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

12:00.quote: “It is not twelve o'clock yet
12:00.title: The Valley of Fear
12:00.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

12:00.quote:
Barnicot was due at his surgery at twelve o'clock, and you can imagine
his amazement when, on arriving there, he found that the window had been
opened in the night, and that the broken pieces of his second bust were
strewn all over the room
12:00.title: The Valley of Fear
12:00.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

12:00.quote:
Harding would be
absent until after noon, and that he was himself a newcomer who could
give us no information
12:00.title: The Valley of Fear
12:00.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

12:00.quote:
Marker is prepared to swear
that the Professor was still in his night-clothes, and, indeed, it was
impossible for him to dress without the help of Mortimer, whose orders
were to come at twelve o'clock
12:00.title: The Valley of Fear
12:00.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

12:00.quote:
He had
actually arrived at twelve o'clock, and appeared to be overwhelmed
by the unexpected tragedy
12:00.title: The Valley of Fear
12:00.author: Arthur Conan Doyle

12:00.quote:
At noon the hour of recreation arrived; at
one o’clock we had lunch; this got on the time, and at last St
12:00.title: The Tenant of Wildfell Hall
12:00.author: Anne Brontë

12:00.quote:
Before noon, all the works
were carried, and the town was in the enemy's hands
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote:
At last the fateful morning dawned; but an impenetrable fog, which
spread over the plain, delayed the attack till noon
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote:
No particular time was fixed for the sitting of the
court; the members, however, assembled at noon, as often as the duke
thought good
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote:
He
endured this situation until noon the ensuing day, when an iron wicket
in the centre of the tower was opened, and two hands were seen lowering
a basket, containing food like that he had found the preceding night
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote: At noon to-morrow I'll hear your sentiments
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote: 'Tis well--at noon to-morrow
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote: We expect them here at noon
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote:
You'll not forget that yet ere noon we meet
The noble envoy at the general's palace
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote: To-day at noon I could not
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote:
A fascinated being I discover,
Whom his two eyes befool, whom passion wilders,
Whom not the broadest light of noon can heal
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote:
They were obliged to pass this way at noon,
As they were coming from the council house
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote:
At noon he wore a look of lofty triumph,
And vowed his joy at the king's choice of me
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote: To-morrow noon I will expect you both
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote:
Yes; he promised
To come again at noon
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote:
Pale at its ghastly noon,
   Pauses above the death-still wood--the moon
12:00.title: Two Treatises of Government
12:00.author: John Locke

12:00.quote:
Douglas was for hours--from
noon till nine o'clock in the evening--obliged to defend himself
against a half-dozen able and eloquent senators
12:00.title: Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm
12:00.author: Kate Douglas Wiggin

12:00.quote:
Flight



   Voices out of the shade that cried,
    And long noon in the hot calm places,
   And children's play by the wayside,
    And country eyes, and quiet faces --
    All these were round my steady paces
12:00.title: The Memoirs of Barry Lyndon
12:00.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

12:00.quote:
Menelaus bold
    Waxed garrulous, and sacked a hundred Troys
    'Twixt noon and supper
12:00.title: The Memoirs of Barry Lyndon
12:00.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

12:00.quote:
Your magic and your beauty and your strength,
   Like hills at noon or sunlight on a tree,
   Sleeping prevail in earth and air
12:00.title: The Memoirs of Barry Lyndon
12:00.author: William Makepeace Thackeray

12:00.quote: Great business must be wrought ere noon
12:00.title: Macbeth
12:00.author: William Shakespeare

12:00.quote: I give you both till to-morrow at noon
12:00.title: The Soul of Man Under Socialism
12:00.author: Oscar Wilde

12:00.quote:
Precisely at noon, the old lady
came to offer me her arm and conduct me formally to a little
box-bordered garden which, with a bit of adjoining meadow, now
constitutes the sole domain of the Porhoëts
12:00.title: The Bulpington of Blup
12:00.author: H.G. Wells

12:00.quote:
Paul and Florence
went out in the meantime on the beach with Wickam—who was constantly in
tears—and at about noon Mrs Pipchin presided over some Early Readings
12:00.title: Bleak House
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
Oh happy Saturdays, when Florence always came at noon,
and never would, in any weather, stay away, though Mrs Pipchin snarled
and growled, and worried her bitterly
12:00.title: Bleak House
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
As these reflections presented themselves to the Captain’s mind, and by
slow degrees assumed this shape and form, his visage cleared like a
doubtful morning when it gives place to a bright noon
12:00.title: Bleak House
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
It is so difficult for the young and ardent, even with such
experience as hers, to imagine youth and ardour quenched like a weak
flame, and the bright day of life merging into night, at noon, that
hope was strong yet
12:00.title: Bleak House
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote:
Next
morning it was there; at noon; at night Darkest and most distinct at
night, as is now to be told
12:00.title: Bleak House
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote: Of morning, noon, and sunset; night, and the rising of an early moon
12:00.title: Bleak House
12:00.author: Charles Dickens

12:00.quote: At noon, I went home, for dinner
12:00.title: The History of England
12:00.author: Thomas Babington Macaulay

12:00.quote:
The Merry Monarch lived through that night, and died before noon on the
next day, which was Friday, the sixth
12:00.title: The Brothers Karamazov
12:00.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky

12:00.quote:
Certainly a superficial view of the British working class in its high
noon of full employment, security, high wages, and new housing would
seem to confirm this conclusion
12:00.title: The Works of Edgar Allan Poe Volume 5
12:00.author: Edgar Allan Poe

12:00.title: The Souls of Black Folk
12:00.author: W.E.B. Du Bois

12:00.quote:
For three times in the day
the new sun-worshipper went out on his little balcony, in the face
of all Westminster, to say some litany to his shining lord: once at
daybreak, once at sunset, and once at the shock of noon
12:00.title: The Souls of Black Folk
12:00.author: W.E.B. Du Bois

12:00.quote:
And it
was while the shock of noon still shook faintly from the towers of
Parliament and parish church that Father Brown, the friend of Flambeau,
first looked up and saw the white priest of Apollo
12:00.title: The Souls of Black Folk
12:00.author: W.E.B. Du Bois

12:00.quote:
Father
Brown could not look at anything without blinking; but the priest of
Apollo could look on the blaze at noon without a quiver of the eyelid
12:00.title: The Souls of Black Folk
12:00.author: W.E.B. Du Bois

12:00.quote:
A hundred people will go into the
witness-box and say that I was standing out upon the balcony of my own
rooms above from just before the stroke of noon to a quarter-past--the
usual period of my public prayers
12:00.title: The Souls of Black Folk
12:00.author: W.E.B. Du Bois

12:00.quote:
You are invited.”

“Not before?—not to-night or to-morrow morning or to-morrow noon or
night
12:00.title: The Awakening
12:00.author: Kate Chopin

12:00.quote: or the day after morning or noon
12:00.title: The Awakening
12:00.author: Kate Chopin

00:00.quote:
You shall hear more by
midnight
00:00.title: Julius Caesar
00:00.author: William Shakespeare

00:00.quote: As I remember, it was almost midnight when we took our leave
00:00.title: David Copperfield
00:00.author: Charles Dickens

00:00.quote:
Often and often we pursued these debates until the clock pointed to
midnight, and the candles were burning down
00:00.title: David Copperfield
00:00.author: Charles Dickens

00:00.quote: It was two or three hours past midnight when I got home
00:00.title: David Copperfield
00:00.author: Charles Dickens

00:00.quote:
‘But say you’ll let me
stop, and see you write.’

‘Why, what a sight for such bright eyes at midnight!’ I replied
00:00.title: David Copperfield
00:00.author: Charles Dickens

00:00.quote: It was midnight when I arrived at home
00:00.title: David Copperfield
00:00.author: Charles Dickens

00:00.quote:
Last night, Traddles, with this journey before her, it was almost
midnight before she came home
00:00.title: David Copperfield
00:00.author: Charles Dickens

00:00.quote:
But, although it was nearly midnight when I came
out of the yard in a chaise, followed by what I had in charge, there
were many people waiting
00:00.title: David Copperfield
00:00.author: Charles Dickens

00:00.quote:
Thoroughly tired, I went to bed too, at midnight; passed the next day on
the Dover coach; burst safe and sound into my aunt’s old parlour while
she was at tea (she wore spectacles now); and was received by her, and
Mr
00:00.title: David Copperfield
00:00.author: Charles Dickens

00:00.quote:
Not so my excellent uncle, Professor
Hardwigg; he studied, he consumed the midnight oil, he pored over heavy
tomes, and digested huge quartos and folios in order to keep the

"It is said that the committee will report the bill back to-morrow

"Then consound it, we've fooled away all this work for nothing

Oft have I struggled with myself, and oft
At midnight, when my guards were sunk in sleep,
With floods of burning tears I've sunk before
The image of the ever-blessed Virgin,
And craved a filial heart, but all in vain

eggs of a yellowish olive color, curiously scrawled with brown and

04:57.quote:
During April, they lay from three to
five buffy white eggs, the shell of which is very rough and hard

They
lay from three to five eggs having a slight gloss

They lay from three to five eggs of a
greenish blue color, covered with a chalky white deposit

04:57.author: Mark Twain

02:00.quote:

02:00.quote:

02:00.author: William Shakespeare

02:00.author: William Shakespeare

at two o'clock
02:00.title: Cranford
02:00.author: Elizabeth Gaskell

02:00.quote:
No wonder Job went over his main points again--

02:00.author: Elizabeth Gaskell

at two o'clock; for, I can tell him, I'll not trust none of his
clerks for hunting up Will, if Jem's life's to depend on it."

Now Mary disliked this plan inexpressibly; her dislike was partly
grounded on reason, and partly on feeling
02:00.title: Cranford
02:00.author: Elizabeth Gaskell

02:00.quote:

Bridgnorth at two

02:00.author: Anton Chekhov

go at two o'clock, and it was only half-past one when he had finished

12:55.quote: “Five minutes to one,” said Nicholl
12:55.title: From the Earth to the Moon
12:55.author: Jules Verne

12:55.quote:
So the chances are four to two, or five to one, that the
war will at no time during the evening become the topic of conversation;
and the chances are still greater that if it become the topic it will
remain so but a little while
12:55.title: Roughing It
12:55.author: Mark Twain

12:55.quote: “Five minutes to one,” said Nicholl
12:55.title: From the Earth to the Moon
12:55.author: Jules Verne

12:55.quote:
So the chances are four to two, or five to one, that the
war will at no time during the evening become the topic of conversation;
and the chances are still greater that if it become the topic it will
remain so but a little while
12:55.title: Roughing It
12:55.author: Mark Twain

12:55.quote:
It is the rule in war, if our forces are ten to the enemy’s one, to
surround him; if five to one, to attack him;

[Straightway, without waiting for any further advantage.]


if twice as numerous, to divide our army into two

12:55.author: Sunzi, active 6th century B.C.

12:55.quote:
We had no weapons, and if we did try to do any damage, with

women; that we had found out to our sorrow

12:55.quote:

12:55.quote:
Their
numbers must be few, and it is five to one they may be accessible by a

12:55.quote: They were five to one, and his Gippies were demoralised

01:17.quote:

his cabin, when his attention was attracted by a distant hissing noise

01:17.quote:

of the Columbiad fell into the Pacific

2:22] Thus
I say, being hot for heaven, by virtue only of the sense and fear

cool also

This man--our lackey, our servant, our
unquestioning slave though he was--was still a gentleman--we could see
that--while of the other two one was coarse and awkward and the other was
a born pirate

02:01.author: Mark Twain

02:01.quote:
Chapter Two

One night towards eleven o’clock they were awakened by the noise of
a horse pulling up outside their door

02:01.quote:
“Two One-Pound notes?”

Nothing less than two fat sweltering one-pound notes that seemed to
have been on terms of the warmest intimacy with all the cattle-markets
in the county
02:01.title: Great Expectations
02:01.author: Charles Dickens

02:01.quote:
The very first
words I heard them interchange as I became conscious, were the words of
my own thought, “Two One Pound notes.”

“How did he get ’em?” said the convict I had never seen
02:01.title: Great Expectations
02:01.author: Charles Dickens

02:01.quote:
Giv him by friends, I expect.”

“I wish,” said the other, with a bitter curse upon the cold, “that I
had ’em here.”

“Two one pound notes, or friends?”

“Two one pound notes
